\section{Splitting of a rotating string }
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%


The rotating closed string solution is given by:
\begin{equation}
X=L \cos(2\sigma  ) \cos(2 \tau) \ ,\ \ \ Y=L\cos(2 \sigma  )\sin(2\tau ) \ ,\ \ \ \ X^0=2L\tau \ ,
\label{ccero}
\end{equation}
where $\sigma  \in [0,\pi)$. This represents a spinning folded closed string with maximum angular momentum.
The coefficient $2L$ in $X^0$ is fixed  by the constraint
$\dot X \cdot \dot X + {X'\cdot X'}=0$ (the other constraint $\dot X\cdot X'=0$ is also satisfied).
The string has energy and angular momentum given by
\begin{equation}
E=M={L\over\a '}\ ,\ \ \ \ \ J={L^2\over 2\a'}\ ,
\end{equation}
so that one has the usual Regge relation $\a'M^2=2J$.


The closed string (\ref{ccero}) contains two segments, the ``upper'' 
segment described by $0<\sigma  < {\pi\over 2}$ and the ``lower'' 
segment described by ${\pi\over 2} <\sigma  < {\pi}$. The full length 
of the string is $4L$. We assume that at $\tau=0 $ the string 
splits into two pieces of lengths $4L_\I $ and $4L_{\II }$, 
$X^\mu (\sigma  )\to \{ X^\mu_\I (\sigma  ), X^\mu_{\II } (\sigma  ) \} \ ,$ 
with $L_\I+L_\II=L$. The initial conditions for the strings I and 
II are given by the string (\ref{ccero}) at $\tau=0 $. 
 The splitting occurs at $\sigma  ={a\pi \over 2}$
for the upper segment, with $a$ defined as
\begin{equation}
\cos a\pi \equiv -{L_\I-L_{\II}\over L}\ , \ \ \ \ 0<a<1\ .
\end{equation}
{}For the lower segment, the splitting is at $\sigma =\pi -{a\pi\over 2} $.
Thus the initial conditions are: 
\begin{equation}
X^\mu_\I (\sigma  ,0)=X^\mu (\sigma , 0)\ ,\ \ \ 
\dot X^\mu_\I (\sigma  ,0)=\dot X^\mu (\sigma , 0)\ ,\
\label{cdoz}
\end{equation}
for $ 0<\sigma < {a\pi\over 2}$ (upper segment) and 
for $\pi >\sigma > \pi -{a\pi\over 2} $ (lower segment),
while for the string II we have
\begin{equation}
X^\mu_{\II }(\sigma  ,0)=X^\mu (\sigma , 0)\ ,\ \ \ 
\dot X^\mu_{\II }(\sigma  ,0)=\dot X^\mu (\sigma , 0)\ ,\ 
\label{cunos}
\end{equation}
for ${a\pi\over 2} <\sigma < {\pi\over 2}$ (upper segment) and   
for ${\pi\over 2} <\sigma < \pi -{a\pi\over 2} $ (lower segment).
These boundary conditions uniquely determine the solution
describing the two closed string final states.

We shall determine the solution describing the two outgoing solutions
in two different ways: 

\smallskip

\noindent a) By explicitly finding the Fourier modes. This will show, in particular,
that the outgoing strings are in a highly excited state which is not of
maximum angular momentum.

\noindent b) By a direct matching with the original solution and imposing the new
periodicity. By construction, the resulting solutions
coincide with the explicit calculation of a), and thus this method provides a 
simple closed analytic formula for the
resummation of the Fourier expansion. This form of the solution also exhibits the
nature of the motion of the outgoing strings I and II.

\subsection{Fourier analysis}
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%


Let us consider the string I. To find the explicit solution,
 we start with the general solution to the string equations 
for the closed string. The condition (\ref{cdoz}) can be equivalently imposed 
in the interval $-{a\pi\over 2} >\sigma > {a\pi\over 2}$,
since the original solution is periodic in $\sigma  $ with period $\pi $.
The most general closed string solution satisfying the periodicity condition 
$X^\mu_\I(\sigma +\pi a)=X^\mu_\I(\sigma  )$ is given by
\begin{equation}
X_\I (\sigma ,\tau )=x_{0\I}+ 2\a' p_\I ^x\ {\tau \over a}+
i \sum_{n\neq 0} \bigg( x_n e^{-2i {n\over a}(\tau -\sigma  )}+
\td x_n e^{-2i {n\over a}(\tau +\sigma  )} \bigg) \ ,
\label{ffz}
\end{equation}
\begin{equation}
Y_\I (\sigma ,\tau )=y_{0\I}+ 2\a' p_\I ^y\ {\tau \over a} +
i \sum_{n\neq 0} \bigg( y_n e^{-2i {n\over a}(\tau -\sigma  )}+
\td y_n e^{-2i {n\over a}(\tau +\sigma  )} \bigg) \ .
\label{ggz}
\end{equation}
Note that the constraints
$$
\dot X\cdot X' =0\ ,\ \ \ \ \dot X \cdot \dot X + {X'\cdot X'}=0\ ,
$$
are satisfied automatically once we impose the initial conditions. 
Indeed,  they are satisfied at $\tau =0$, because there
the solutions $X_I^\mu, \ X_{II}^\mu$ and their first derivatives
coincide with the original solution $X^\mu $, which already satisfies the constraints.
Since they are a constant of motion, then they are satisfied for all $\tau $
(using the fact that $T_{++}=T_{++}(\sigma ^+)\ ,\ \ T_{--}=T_{--}(\sigma ^-)$, one sees that
the condition $T_{++}=T_{--}=0$ at $\tau=0$ implies that they vanish for any $\tau $). 



 Let us first 
 determine the conserved quantum numbers, energy, linear momentum and
angular momentum of each string. Since they are conserved 
quantities, they can be found at $\tau =0$, where the solution is 
given by eq.~(\ref{cdoz}), (\ref{cunos}). The energy  and  linear 
momentum components are given by 
\begin{eqnarray} 
E_\I &=& {2\over 2\pi \a' 
}\int_0^{{\pi a\over 2} } d\sigma \ \dot X^0_\I ={La\over \a' }\ ,
\\ 
p_\I^x &=& 0\ ,\ 
\\
p_\I^y &=& {2\over 2\pi \a' } 
\int_0^{{\pi a\over 2}}d\sigma \ \dot Y_\I={4L\over 2\pi \a'} 
\int_0^{{\pi a\over 2}} d\sigma \ \cos(2\sigma  )={L\sin(\pi a)\over \pi 
\a' }\ . 
\end{eqnarray}
There is an extra factor of two in the above expressions, which takes into account 
that there are two segments of string giving the same contribution.
The angular momentum is 
\begin{equation} 
J_\I={2\over 2\pi 
\a'}\int_0^{{\pi a\over 2} }(X_\I\dot Y_\I-\dot X_\I 
Y_\I)={L^2a\over 2 \a'}\ \left (1+{\sin(2\pi a)\over 2\pi 
a}\right)\ . 
\end{equation} 
This has an orbital component $l_\I $ and spin 
component $S_\I$. Since $p^x_\I=0$, the orbital component is just 
$l_\I=x_{0\I}p^y_\I$, where $x_{0\I}$ is the center of mass 
coordinate of the string I, 
\begin{equation} 
x_{0\I}={2\over \pi 
a}\int_0^{{\pi a\over 2}} d\sigma \ X_\I ={L\sin(\pi a)\over \pi a 
}={\a' \over a}\ p^y_\I \ .
\end{equation} 
Therefore $J_\I=l_\I+S_\I$ with 
\begin{equation} 
l_\I={L^2a\over \a' }\ {\sin^2(\pi a)\over (\pi a)^2} \ ,\ \ \ \ 
S_\I ={L^2a\over 2 \a'}\ \left (1- {2\sin^2(\pi a)\over (\pi a)^2} 
+{\sin(2\pi a)\over 2\pi a}\right) \ .
\label{orbe}
\end{equation} 
The mass of the string I 
is thus given by 
\begin{equation} 
M^2_\I= E_\I^2- p_\I^2={L^2\over  {\a'}^2} 
\left( a^2 - {\sin^2(\pi a)\over \pi ^2} \right) \ .
\end{equation} 

Let us now 
determine the oscillator modes. {}From the conditions $\dot X_\I 
(\sigma  ,0)=\dot X (\sigma , 0)=0$, $Y_\I (\sigma  ,0)=Y (\sigma , 0)=0$, it follows 
that 
\begin{equation} 
x_n=\td x_{-n}\ ,\ \ \ \ \ y_n=-\td y_{-n}\ .\ 
\end{equation} 
To 
find $x_n$, $y_n$, we multiply the two remaining boundary conditions $ X_\I (\sigma  
,0)= X (\sigma , 0)$, $\dot Y_\I (\sigma  ,0)=\dot Y (\sigma , 0)=0$ by 
$e^{-2i{n\over a}\sigma  }$ and perform the integral over $\sigma  $ from 
$-{a\pi\over 2}$ to ${a\pi\over 2}$ , using the expansions 
(\ref{ffz}), (\ref{ggz}) and the solution (\ref{ccero}). We find 
\begin{equation} 
X_\I={L\sin(\pi a)\over \pi a} \left( 1+2\sum_{n=1}^\infty 
{(-1)^n\over 1-{n^2\over a^2} } \cos({2n\tau\over a})  
\cos({2n\sigma \over a}) \right) \ ,
\label{solux} 
\end{equation} 
\begin{equation} 
Y_\I={L\sin(\pi a)\over \pi a} \left( 2\tau +2a \sum_{n=1}^\infty 
{(-1)^n\over n(1-{n^2\over a^2}) } \sin({2n\tau\over a})  
\cos({2n\sigma \over a}) \right) \ ,
\label{soluy} 
\end{equation} 
where $-{\pi a\over 2}<\sigma <{\pi a\over 2}$ (note that the factor 
$(-1)^n$ can be removed byshifting $\sigma  $ so that
 $0<\sigma <{\pi a}$).
Finally, we have 
$X^0_\I=2L\tau $.

Let us now consider the string II.
The solution is readily found by noting that the Fourier analysis become the same in terms of
 $a'=1-a$ and $\sigma '=\sigma -{\pi\over 2}$.
We have to take into account that the shift in $\sigma  $ produces a change of sign in the solution 
(\ref{ccero}).
We get
\begin{equation}
X_\II=-{L\sin(\pi a)\over \pi (1-a)} \left( 1+2\sum_{n=1}^\infty {(-1)^n\over 1-{n^2\over (1-a)^2} } 
\cos({2n\tau\over (1-a)})  \cos({2n\sigma \over (1-a)}) \right)
\label{dsolux}
\end{equation}
\begin{equation}
Y_\II=-{L\sin(\pi a)\over \pi (1-a)} \left( 2\tau +2(1-a) \sum_{n=1}^\infty 
{(-1)^n\over n(1-{n^2\over (1-a)^2}) } \sin({2n\tau\over (1-a)})  \cos({2n\sigma \over (1-a)}) \right)
\label{dsoluy}
\end{equation}
with $-{\pi (1-a)\over 2}<\sigma <{\pi (1-a)\over 2}$, and $X^0_\II=2L\tau $.

The conserved quantities for the 
string II are
\begin{equation} 
E_{\II } 
={L(1-a)\over \a' }\ ,\ \ \ \ p_{\II }^y=-{L\sin(\pi a)\over \pi 
\a' } \ ,
\end{equation} 
\begin{equation} 
J_{\II }=l_{\II }+S_{\II }\ ,\ \ \ \  
l_{\II }={L^2(1-a)\over \a' }\ {\sin^2(\pi a)\over (\pi (1-a))^2} \ 
,\ 
\label{orbis}
\end{equation} 
\begin{equation}  
S_{\II }={L^2(1-a)\over 2 \a'}\ \left (1- 
{2\sin^2(\pi a)\over (\pi (1-a))^2} - {\sin(2\pi a)\over 2\pi 
(1-a)}\right) \ ,
\end{equation} 
\begin{equation} M^2_{\II }= E_\II^2- p_\II^2={L^2\over  
{\a'}^2} \left( (1-a)^2 - {\sin^2(\pi a)\over \pi ^2} \right) \ .
\end{equation}

One easily checks that energy, linear momentum and angular momentum
are conserved in the process of splitting,
\begin{equation}
E_\I+E_\II ={L\over\a '}=E\ ,\ \ \ \ p_\I^y+p_\II^y=0\ ,\ \ \ \ \ 
J_\I+J_\II={L^2\over 2\a'}=J\ .
\end{equation}
We stress that the outgoing strings represent excited string states which do not 
have maximum angular momentum.

The two pieces are folded like the initial string and the splitting occurs 
at $\sigma ={a\pi\over 2}$ in the upper segment and at $\sigma =\pi-{a\pi\over 2}$ in the lower segment,
with $0<a<1$. The two resulting strings are determined as in the previous subsection
by requiring continuity

The resulting expressions for $Y_{\I,\II}$ are the sum of two terms.
One term corresponds to the momentum carried by the string:

It is convenient to rescale the world-sheet parameters of the resulting strings

\nonumber \\

\label{stringauno}

where
\begin{eqnarray}
&C_\I(\sigma  )&=\cos(2a\sigma  ) \ , \ \ S_\I (\sigma  )=\sin(2a\sigma  )-{2\sin(a\pi )\over \pi}\sigma   \nonumber\\
&{\rm for}& \ \  0\leq \sigma  < {\pi\over 2} \ , \nonumber \\
&C_\I(\sigma  )&=\cos(2a\sigma -a2\pi) \ , \ \ S_\I(\sigma  )=\sin(2a\sigma -a2\pi )-{2\sin(a\pi )\over \pi}(\sigma  -\pi )
 \nonumber\\

Similarly for the string $\II$ we get:
\begin{eqnarray}
&&X^0_{\II\pm}(\sigma ^\pm )=\pm {L}(1-a)\sigma ^\pm \ ,
\nonumber \\
&&X_{\II\pm}(\sigma ^\pm )={L\over  2}C_{\II}(\sigma ^\pm )  , \
\nonumber\\

\label{stringadue}

where
\begin{eqnarray}
&&C_{\II}(\sigma  )=\cos(2(1-a)\sigma  + a\pi) \ , \ \
\nonumber\\ 
&&S_{\II}(\sigma  )=\sin(2(1-a)\sigma  + a\pi)+{2\sin(a\pi )\over \pi}\sigma  
\nonumber\\
 &&{\rm for} \  \ 0\leq \sigma  < \pi \ .

\section{Comparison with the superstring  quantum calculation}
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%

The decay process described above by semiclassical splitting predicts that masses will 
be related by the following formulas:
\begin{equation} 
M_\I= M_\I (a)= {L\over  {\a'}} \sqrt{a^2 - {\sin^2(\pi 
a)\over \pi ^2} }\ ,
\label{asd}
\end{equation} 
\begin{equation} M_{\II }=M_{\II}(a ) ={L\over  
{\a'}} \sqrt{ (1-a)^2 - {\sin^2(\pi a)\over \pi ^2} }\ .
\label{zxc}
\end{equation}
These relations define a function $M_\I=M_\I(M_\II )$.
 
In ref.~\cite{IR},
the full quantum calculation of the decay was done in the ten dimensional type II superstring theory.
The decay rate is obtained by extracting the imaginary part of
the genus one self-energy of the massive particle:
$\Gamma ={\rm Im}{\Delta M^2\over 2M}$. 

This calculation is complicated: it combines expansions of theta functions and resummations, 
saddle-point   evaluation of some integrals. Nevertheless, it is an exact genus one result 
in the large $M$ limit, since the only approximation involved are saddle-point approximations, 
which become exact as $\a'M^2\gg 1$. 

Here we explain briefly the idea of the method and the result. 
We compute the contribution to ${\rm Im}(\Delta M^2)$ of the decay channel 
corresponding to the states with masses $M_1, M_2$: let us call  
${d^2{\rm Im}(\Delta M^2)\over  dM^2_1dM^2_2}$ that contribution per unit  $ dM^2_1dM^2_2$.
The one-loop self-energy, derived first in \cite{IK}, 
is represented as an integral of some combination of theta functions, 
the integration being over the torus complex modulus and over a complex 
(vertex position) coordinate on the torus surface. The integration is formally divergent,
and it is computed by a standard analytic continuation. 

A key point is to write the integrand as a sum of holomorphically factorized quantities.
The selection of a particular decay channel corresponds to a particular
 term in the Taylor expansion of the holomorphic factors, as it is recognized
by comparison with field theory Feynman diagrams. 
Cauchy contour integrals and  saddle point techniques 
are used for getting the holomorphic expansion, similarly to the well known
procedure for computing the entropy of a state in string theory.    
In this way we obtained:
\begin{equation}
{d^2{\rm Im}(\Delta M^2)\over  dM^2_1dM^2_2}\sim M^{-3}\exp[2M^2 S_0(M_1/M,M_2/M)]\ ,
\label{quantum}
\end{equation}
with $S_0\leq 0$ (given in fig.~1 of \cite{IR}). 



Therefore in the large mass limit the dominant decay channel corresponds to values 
of $M_{1,2}$
for which $S_0=0$, i.e. the masses of the 
decay products are correlated, modulo processes which are 
exponentially suppressed. 
This effect may come as a surprise, 
since one might have expected a sizable string vertex coupling
three string states of arbitrary masses $M,\ M_1,\ M_2$.

Figure 1 shows the relation $M_\I=M_\I^{\rm quantum }(M_\II )$, 
corresponding to $S_0=0$, found numerically in \cite{IR} (and shown there in fig.~3).
.

defined by (\ref{asd}), (\ref{zxc}).

\section{Decay rate and description of the motion}
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%

There is a simple semiclassical argument which gives directly the
decay rate.

Consider the rotating string (\ref{rotating}). The solution is periodic
with period $T=2\pi L$.
%, and therefore the total probability of splitting 
%in a full cycle must be the same as the total 
% probability of splitting in each cycle.
The probability of splitting per cycle is by definition proportional to the string coupling $g_s^2$.
Thus, the total decay rate per unit time is given by
\begin{equation}
\Gamma ={\rm probability\ per\ cycle \over period  }= {\rm const.} \ 
{g_s^2\over 2\pi L}= {\rm const.}\ {g_s^2\over \a' M} \ .
\end{equation}
Thus the lifetime of a massive string with maximum angular momentum is given by
\begin{equation}
{\cal T}= \Gamma^{-1}= {\rm const.}\ {\a '\over g_s^2}\ M\ .
\end{equation}

This result for the lifetime  coincides with that of the quantum calculation 
performed in \cite{IR}:
in fact this is what is obtained by computing  ${\rm Im}(\Delta M^2)$ 
as the sum over $M^2_1,M^2_2$
of the result (\ref{quantum}). 
Thus, a classical estimate confirms the surprising result of \cite{IR}, that is 
a string with maximum angular momentum becomes more stable the more massive it is.


Let us also remark that, independently of any computation, a strictly classical
estimate for the string lifetime can only be ${\cal T} \sim L$, because $L$ is the
only time scale of the classical string (in units $c=1$); indeed the classical
string solution does not know $\hbar$ nor $\a'$, which only appear in the 
interpretation of classical parameters as quantities having dimensions of energy, like
for instance $M=\hbar L/\a'$. An exponential factor containing $\a'$ in the denominator
of the exponent can be expected in a semiclassical computation. In fact, this is the
form of our result, the sum over $M^2_1,M^2_2$ of (\ref{quantum}): 
\begin{equation}
{\cal T}=  {\rm const.}L \exp[-2{L^2\over  \a'}S_0^{Max}]\ .
\end{equation}
We have seen that in general $S_0\leq 0$ and that the maximum of $S_0$  
corresponds to the classical solution for which $S_0^{Max}=0$.


Having the exact semiclassical solutions for the outgoing strings I and II, 
it is interesting to describe the main features of their motion.
Figures 3 and 4 are  plots of a sequence of pictures of the string I 
and II after the splitting, for different breaking points: $a=0.4$, $a=0.15$ respectively.
We see that the outgoing closed string remain folded, exhibiting a rotating motion.
The figures 3 and 4 were made using the Fourier series formulas of section 2.1.
One can check  that the same plot is obtained using the
formulas of section 2.2.
Figures 5,6,7 are a plot of the world-sheet for the breaking point at $a=0.4$.





The most salient feature that can be observed from the figure is that  
the breaking of the strings creates  an angular bending, or kink, which 
then travels back and forth all along each string.
Remarkably, each string is straight except at the bending point.
One might wonder whether this feature is generic, at least 
for the breaking of an open string:
the kink is produced by the jump of the first derivative at the splitting point; it
is locally created, thus its
occurrence should not depend on whether the string has maximum angular momentum 
(i.e. whether it is straight or  curved).


Another important feature is that the angles of the bendings of the strings I and II
sum up $180^{\rm o}$, and they are given by
\begin{equation}
\theta_\I = a\pi\ ,\ \ \  \theta_\II=(1-a) \pi \ .
\label{angulos}
\end{equation} 
Note that they are in relation with the energies of the strings.
When $a=1/2$  both angles are $\pi/2$.



The formulas (\ref{angulos}) can be proved by using the solutions of section 2.2.
Consider the string I at a given instant $\tau $. 
The derivative ${dY_\I\over dX_\I}$ has the same discontinuity in both upper 
and lower segments of the closed string. In one segment the discontinuity
 originates from the discontinuity in $\partial_\sigma  X_{\I +}$ at 
$\sigma _1 ={\pi\over 2}-\tau $. In the other segment, it originates 
from the discontinuity of 
$\partial_\sigma  X_{\I -}$ at $\sigma _2 ={\pi\over 2}+\tau $.

{}For $a<1/2$, the bending angle $\theta_I$ of the string I is an acute angle.
It can be computed in particular at $\sigma _1 $, where it is given by
\begin{equation}
\theta_\I=\arctan{dY_\I\over dX_\I}\bigg|_{\sigma _1-\epsilon}
 -\arctan{dY_\I\over dX_\I}\bigg|_{\sigma _1+\epsilon} \ .
\end{equation}
Using the explicit form of the solutions, we obtain
$$
{dY_\I\over dX_\I}\bigg|_{\sigma _1-\epsilon} = 
{\partial_\sigma  Y\over \partial_\sigma  X}\bigg|_{\sigma _1-\epsilon}=\tan(2a \tau)\ ,
$$
\begin{equation}
{dY_\I\over dX_\I}\bigg|_{\sigma _1+\epsilon} = \tan(2a \tau-a\pi  )\ .
\end{equation}
Thus
\begin{equation}
\theta_\I=2a\tau-(2a\tau-a\pi)  =a\pi\ .
\end{equation}
Similarly, one finds $\theta_\II $ as in (\ref{angulos}).
